subsc: Other social services,Crops,Forestry,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector,Sub-national government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment is that the
            project outcome was satisfactory. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory. Project
            sustainability is likely. Lessons included the following:
            States needed sufficient time and support at the beginning
            of projects to set up planning procedures and systems and to
            fully involve the communities in defining their needs and
            involvement. The success of constituted user groups
            emphasized the importance of the government strongly
            supporting and promoting the establishment and involvement
            of local village organizations. This project's success
            depended on project design including community awareness
            building, farmer and community training, savings schemes
            promotion, and interventions that provided short-, as well
            as medium- and long-term benefits to individual farmers and
            communities. On the other hand, technical support for the
            project was too narrowly confined to adaptive agricultural
            research. The project gave little direct emphasis to
            women's needs and aspirations; it should have focused
            on forming specific women user groups, and training women in
            village-based income-generating activities. Policy and
            action plans should have emphasized restrictimg livestock
            numbers, combined with more active programs to exclude
            grazing and rehabilitate forest areas. Benefits would have
            acrued with more inter-agency collaboration. Lastly,
            nongovernmental organizations should have been participated
            in initial planning and received training.
